author: Coral Barry
title: England to pay tribute to London terror attack victims on Sunday before Lithuania game
text:
England wore blue against Germany on Wednesday (Picture: Getty) England did not wear black armbands against Germany on Wednesday night, but will pay tribute to the London terror attack victims at Wembley on Sunday.
Antonio Conte report card: Near-perfect start with Chelsea on course for the double The FA announced that plans were underway to honour the victims who tragically lost their lives in Westminster before the game against Lithuania.
A terror attack killed four people with at least 20 others injured and the FA released a statement ahead of the Germany game.
‘Our thoughts are with all of those who have been affected by this terrible incident,’ said FA chairman Greg Clarke.
England wore black armbands after a terror attack in France last November (Picture: Getty) ‘We will be recognising the bravery of the security services and all those involved at the England versus Lithuania match on Sunday.’
England welcome Lithuania to Wembley on Sunday in the second friendly game of their international fixtures this week.
Three Lions boss Gareth Southgate said the attacks put football into perspective.
‘Our first thoughts are with the families of those that lost their lives, that have been injured. It puts football into perspective at a moment like that,’ he told ITV.

‘For us we’re concious that part of our identity as a nation is that we carry on in moments like this so it’s important that we represent our country in the right way tonight.
‘In terms of any tribute we felt in London on Sunday would be the right thing.’
